questions.text: A woman was diagnosed to have metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with CK 7 (+) and CK20 (-) IHC markers. Which of the following is the most likely primary site of origin for this metastasis?
questions.solution:
The most likely origin of metastasis is lung carcinoma, as the IHC of the metastatic tumor revealed CK 7 (+) and CK20 (-).

Cytokeratin profiles of various primary tumors:

        CK 7 Positive

        CK 20 Positive
  • Cholangiocarcinoma
  • Ovarian mucinous carcinoma
  • Transitional cell carcinoma
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma

        CK 7 Positive 

        CK 20 Negative
  • Breast carcinoma
  • Ovarian serous adenocarcinoma
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Thymoma
  • Endometrial carcinoma

        CK 7 Negative

        CK 20 Positive
  • Colorectal adenocarcinoma

        CK 7 Negative

        CK 20 Negative
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Prostatic adenocarcinoma

Related Pearl: Role of CK7 and CK20 Markers in Tumors of Unknown Primary

Cytokeratin is an epithelial marker. A combination of CK7 and CK20 is used to identify the organ of origin.

CK7 CK20 Common Cancers
+

-

 

Breast,

Lung,

Thyroid

 
- + Colorectal
- -

 

Renal

Prostate

Hepatocellular

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. The immunohistochemical studies of this tumor are most likely to express which of the following tumor markers?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text: A 50-year-old postmenopausal woman presented to the clinic with a history of a lump in her right breast for six months. Radiological examination showed an irregular spiculated lesion of 8 mm with microcalcification. A biopsy was taken, and the immunohistochemistry results revealed that the cell membrane was stained brown. Identify the pathophysiological mechanism of the underlying condition.

choices.text: Point mutation of JAK2 receptor gene
Point mutation of EGFR tyrosine kinase

questions.solution:
The mechanism of neoplasia(underlying condition) here is due to the amplification of the ERBB2 gene, resulting in abnormal HER2neu receptors.

The given clinical stem is suggestive of invasive breast carcinoma. The radiological imaging with irregular, spiculated margins and microcalcifications is an indication for biopsy for further assessment. In the immunohistochemistry studies, the cell membrane is stained brown, indicating a HER2neu-positive tumour. Fluorescent in situ hybridisation (FISH) can be used adjunctively to confirm the diagnosis. HER2-positive is the second most common molecular subtype of invasive breast cancer.

HER2 receptors (also known as ERBB2) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that promotes cell proliferation and opposes apoptosis by stimulating the RAS- and PI3K-AKT signalling pathways. 

Immunohistochemistry staining of breast carcinoma - 

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are nuclear receptors, and the nucleus is stained brown.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor. Hence, the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

Other options:-

Option B: Point mutation of the JAK2 receptor gene is seen in myeloproliferative neoplasias. 

Option C: EGFR belongs to the ERBB1 family of transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase. EGFR is essential for the growth and differentiation of epithelial cells. Point mutation of this is the causative mechanism for adenocarcinoma of the lung. 

Option D: Gene amplification of the n-myc gene is seen in neuroblastoma.

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features

ER-positive, HER2- negative

  		  

HER2- Positive (ER- positive or negative)

ER- negative

HER2- negative

Frequency

~40-55% (Low proliferation)

~10% (High proliferation)

~20%

~15%

Included special histologic types

Well or moderately differentiated lobular, tubular, mucinous

Poorly differentiated lobular

Some apocrine

Medullary, adenoid cystic, secretory, metaplastic

Typical patient groups

Older women, men, cancers detected by mammographic screening

BRCA2 mutation carriers

Young women, non-white women, TP53 mutation carrier (ER-positive)

Young women, BRCA1 mutation carriers, African American and Hispanic women

questions.text: Which of the following tumor markers is least useful in assessing dysgerminoma?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not a useful marker for dysgerminoma; it is a marker for endodermal sinus tumors. Dysgerminoma secretes placental alkaline phosphatase, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG.

Dysgerminoma is a type of germ cell tumor corresponding to the testis's seminoma. It does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is usually used to monitor these patients for disease recurrence.

Endodermal sinus tumor/ Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in premenarchal girls. Schiller-Duval bodies are pathognomonic in histopathology. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor and is used as a tumor marker.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: Which of these tumor markers is elevated in carcinoma breast?
questions.solution:
CA-15-3 is elevated in carcinoma breast.

Tumor markers play a crucial role in identifying cancer and are often beneficial for monitoring a tumor's reaction to treatment and detecting its recurrence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female was diagnosed with thyroid carcinoma. The histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is correct regarding the management of this subtype of thyroid carcinoma?

choices.text: Prophylactic neck dissection is not indicated
Paclitaxel is the drug of choice for metastatic disease
Postoperative management includes Radioactive Iodine Ablation (RAI)
Calcitonin and CEA levels testing are used for the follow-up

questions.solution:
The histopathology image shows amyloid-rich stroma and spindle cells, which are characteristic of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC). Calcitonin and CEA are used for the follow-up of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) patients. 

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) arises from the parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid, which are concentrated superolateral in the thyroid and are derived from the neural crest. MTC usually occurs in a sporadic form (80%). It can also occur as inherited syndromes such as Familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. All these variants are associated with germline mutations in the RET proto-oncogene.

Clinical features of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) include,

  • 50-60 years of age (younger age in familial MTC)
  • Mostly unilateral (bilateral and multicentric in familial MTC) 
  • Palpable mass in the thyroid
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy is common
  • Hematogenous spread is also seen. The most common distant metastasis is seen in Liver > Bones (osteoblastic).
  • Dysphagia, dyspnea, or dysphonia (due to local invasion)
  • Diarrhea may occur in 30% of cases (due to 5-hydroxytryptamine or prostaglandins secreted by tumour cells)
  • Some develop Cushing’s syndrome (due to ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone)

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and other peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptides, serotonin, prostaglandins E2 and F2α, and histaminadases.

Diagnosis is made based on the clinical features, raised serum calcitonin, or CEA levels, and FNAB cytology.

All new patients with MTC should be screened for RET point mutations, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism. If patients are found to have a pheochromocytoma, it must be treated first.

Pentagastrin (synthetic gastrin analogue), which increases the basal rate of calcitonin secretion, was formerly used to screen patients with Familial Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC). RET testing has replaced pentagastrin or calcium-stimulated calcitonin levels testing in the screening of patients with familial MTC.

Management of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) is as follows:

Extent of cancer Surgery 

MTC without LN involvement

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection (prophylactic)(Option A)

MTC + central neck nodes involved or tumor size ≥1.5 cm

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection (therapeutic) + Ipsilateral Modified radical neck dissection (prophylactic)

MTC + other LNs involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection + Bilateral Modified radical neck dissection (therapeutic)

Metastatic disease

 

  • Debulking thyroidectomy
  • Chemotherapy -
    • Vandetanib (multi-kinase inhibitor) - drug of choice 
    • Labetuzumab (anti-CEA)
  • External beam radiotherapy

There is no role of Radioactive Iodine Ablation (RAI) (Option C) in MTC as the tumor is not TSH-dependent and doesn’t take up radioactive iodine.

Annual calcitonin and CEA level testing is used for the follow-up of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) patients. Imaging (USG/CT neck and mediastinum, FDG-PET/CT scans) is also useful.

Other options:

Option B - Paclitaxel is used for adjunctive chemotherapy (Adriamycin + Paclitaxel/Cisplatin) in Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma (ATC). It is not a valid chemotherapy option for Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC).

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient was found to have a PSA of 5.6 ng/ml on routine examination and was advised to undergo a TRUS-guided transrectal biopsy. What is the standard biopsy template?

TRUS-Trans Rectal Ultrasound Scan
questions.solution:
The standard biopsy template usually includes 12 biopsies taken from six areas.

Patients who have either an elevated total PSA level (i.e. over 2.5 - 4.0 ng/ml) or abnormal findings on digital rectal examination (DRE) or both are advised to undergo TRUS-guided biopsy of the prostate.

The standard biopsy template involves 12 core biopsies with a spring-loaded biopsy instrument.

Site of biopsy: The tissue is usually obtained from the base, mid, and apex regions, medially and laterally from the left and right sides.

Patients are asked to stop anticoagulants to prevent bleeding complications.

Common adverse effects that follow TRUS biopsy include rectal bleeding, gross hematuria, and hematospermia, all of which are usually self-limited. Fever, urinary infection and retention occur in less than 5% of patients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, pain over the ribs, and confusion. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and increased serum creatinine level. The peripheral smear shows the finding given below. The international prognostic staging system for this disease is based on the levels of which of the following parameters?

choices.text: β2 glycoprotein and plasma light chains

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing a Mott cell suggest a probable diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The international prognostic staging system for multiple myeloma is based on levels of β2 microglobulin and albumin.

Mott cells are plasma cells with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies. They may be seen in African trypanosomiasis and multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia in which there is an unregulated proliferation of plasma cells. The proliferating cells stimulate osteoclastic activity and suppress osteoblastic activity, leading to the formation of multiple lytic bone lesions. These lesions can be seen on radiographs as 'punched out' lesions.  In some severe cases, patients may present with pathological fractures. 

Other features of multiple myeloma:

  • Acute renal failure in a dehydrated state
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia 
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes cause headache, exacerbation, or precipitation of heart failure, visual disturbances, ataxia, and vertigo
  • Bony damage leading to cord compression
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Sensory more than motor neuropathy associated with IgM directed against myelin-associated globulin

The single most important predictor for survival is serum β2-microglobulin. Serum β2-microglobulin, along with serum albumin, forms the basis of the International Staging System for multiple myeloma that predicts survival.

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

 

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Myeloma

Poor prognosis

Good prognosis

t(4;14), MAF translocations t(14;16) and t(14;20), del(17p), aneuploidy, hypodiploidy

Hyperdiploid, t(11;14), t(6;14), cyclin D1 or D3 positive

Elevated beta-2 microglobulin, lactate dehydrogenase, C- reactive protein, plasma-cell proliferation, or bone marrow infiltration

Plasmablastic morphology

Abnormalities by conventional cytogenetics

Plasma labelling index >3%

Serum creatinine level >2mg/dL

Bone marrow biopsy: Diffuse and prominent angiogenesis

Low serum albumin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.solution:
NRG-1 (Neuregulin-1) is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs).

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, the stomach being the most common site. They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells of the GIT. GIST is seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life and has an equal preponderance among males and females. Most patients present with haematemesis, melena, or vague abdominal pain. The most common indications for surgery include bleeding and obstruction.

The GIST may occur in a sporadic form or as part of familial syndromes. In sporadic GIST, the most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRA mutation (8%). Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient GIST is a subset of wild-type GIST seen with Carney triad or Carney-Stratakis syndrome. 

The below image shows the microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumour cells.

Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells, plumper epithelioid cells, or a mixed pattern.

Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) - deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be used instead. 

During surgical resection of GIST, care must be taken to prevent capsule rupture, which causes seeding of nearby tissues leading to relapse in 100% of the cases. If capsule rupture occurs, adjuvant therapy with imatinib is indicated regardless of tumor extent.

Other options:

Option A: KIT (CD117): This is the most well-known marker for GISTs. About 85% of GISTs show mutations in the KIT gene, leading to the expression of the KIT protein on the cell surface. KIT is a receptor tyrosine kinase, and its activation is a key driver in the pathogenesis of GISTs.

Option B: SDH (Succinate Dehydrogenase): SDH mutations are associated with a subset of GISTs, particularly those that are KIT and PDGFRA wild-type. Loss of SDH function is characteristic of this subgroup, and SDH deficiency can be demonstrated through immunohistochemistry.

Option C: PDGFRA (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor Alpha): Mutations in the PDGFRA gene account for approximately 5-10% of GISTs. Similar to KIT, PDGFRA is a receptor tyrosine kinase, and mutations in this gene can lead to the development of GISTs.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child presented with complaints of fatigue, fever, and dyspnea for the past week. Chest X-ray reveals mediastinal widening. Peripheral smear findings are given below. Which of the following findings on immunophenotyping do you expect to find in this case?

MPO: Myeloperoxidase
TdT: Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase
PAS: Periodic acid-Schiff
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 12-year-old child presenting with fatigue, fever, and dyspnea, a chest X-ray showing mediastinal widening, and a peripheral smear showing abundant lymphoblasts (cells with scant cytoplasm and large nucleus) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). ALL will be TdT positive on immunophenotyping.

ALL is the most common cancer in childhood. B-cell ALLs usually present as early childhood leukemias, while T-cell ALLs are usually seen in adolescents as thymic lymphomas. Clinical features include fatigue, infections, bleeding diathesis (due to impaired marrow function), hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and dyspnea due to mediastinal or thymic infiltration.

Initial evaluation involves a routine complete blood count and peripheral smear. It typically reveals anemia, thrombocytopenia, and the presence of blasts (immature WBCs) on the smear. Morphologically, myeloblasts and lymphoblasts may be difficult to distinguish. Immunophenotyping thus plays an important role in confirming the diagnosis.

 

Immunophenotyping
  ALL AML
Immunohistochemistry MPO negative
TdT positive 
PAS positive

MPO positive
TdT negative 
PAS negative
Flow cytometry

Pre-B cell leukemia - 

  • CD10 
  • CD19 
  • CD20 
  • CD22
  • Cytoplasmic IgM heavy chain (μ chain)

Pre-T cell leukemia - 

  • CD1 
  • CD2 
  • CD5
  • CD7

Myeloid blasts - 

  • CD34 (a marker of multipotent stem cells) 
  • Do not express CD64 (a marker of mature myeloid cells)
  • CD33 or CD15 in a few subsets

AML - Acute myelogenous leukemia

Other options:

Option A: MPO positive on immunohistochemistry is a feature of myeloblasts seen in AML. Lymphoblasts are MPO-negative.

Option C: CD33 positive on flow cytometry is a marker of myeloid progenitors and monocytes seen in AML. 

Option D: PAS negative on immunohistochemistry is a feature of myeloblasts seen in AML. Lymphoblasts are usually PAS-positive. 

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

  Lymphoblasts  Myeloblasts 
Blast population Homogeneous Heterogeneous, with the exception of the undifferentiated form 
Size Variable, mainly small  Variable, mainly large 
Nucleus Central, mainly round; sometimes indented. 
 		 Eccentric, round, oval, or angulated; sometimes convoluted, particularly in the form with a monocytic component 
Chromatin Fine, with dispersed condensation. 
Very condensed in small lymphoblasts 		 Fine, granular, delicately dispersed 
Nucleoli Absent in small lymphoblasts. 
Sometimes indistinct 		 Present. Often large and prominent, double or triple 
Cytoplasm Scanty and basophilic.
Sometimes with a single long projection (hand-mirror cell) 		 Variable. 
Abundant in monoblasts, 
with protrusions in erythroblasts and megakaryoblasts 
Granules Rarely present. Negative for peroxidase, esterases, and toluidine blue  Present in forms with differentiation and positive with cytochemical stains
  • Peroxidase in the neutrophil and eosinophil lineages
  • Nonspecific esterase in the monocyte lineage 
Auer rods Absent  Can be present. 
Typically present in the hyper granular promyelocytic form 
Vacuoles Can be present Can be present. 
Almost always present in forms with a monocytic component 

The image given below shows lymphoblasts.

The image given below shows myeloblasts.

Related Pearl: Immune Cell Antigens Detected by Monoclonal Antibodies

Antigen Designation and their Normal Cellular Distribution 
Primarily T-Cell Associated 
  • CD1 Thymocytes and Langerhans cells 
  • CD3 Thymocytes, mature T cells 
  • CD4 Helper T cells, subset of thymocytes  
  • CD5 T cells and a small subset of B cells  
  • CD8 Cytotoxic T cells, subset of thymocytes, and some NK cells 
Primarily B-Cell Associated 
  • CD10 Pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells 
  • CD19 Pre-B cells and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD20 Pre-B cells after CD19 and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD21 EBV receptor; mature B cells and follicular dendritic cells
  • CD23 Activated mature B cells 
  • CD79a Marrow pre-B cells and mature B cells 
Primarily Monocyte or Macrophage Associated 
  • CD11c Granulocytes, monocytes, and macrophages; also expressed by hairy cell leukemias 
  • CD13 Immature and mature monocytes and granulocytes 
  • CD14 Monocytes 
  • CD15 Granulocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants
  • CD33 Myeloid progenitors and monocytes  
  • CD64 Mature myeloid cells  
Primarily NK-CellAssociated 
  • CD16 NK cells and granulocytes  
  • CD56 NK cells and a subset of T cells 
Primarily Stem Cell and Progenitor Cell Associated  
  • CD34 Pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages 
Activation Markers 
  • CD30 Activated B cells, T cells, and monocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants 
Present on All Leukocytes 
  • CD45 All leukocytes; also known as leukocyte common antigen (LCA) 

Related Pearl: Prognostic factors in ALL

Prognostic factors in ALL

 Prognostic factors Good Bad
Age 2-9 years <1 year or >10 years
Sex Female Male
Race White Black
CNS leukemia Absent Overt
Hepatosplenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy Absent Massive
Mediastinal mass Absent Present
Testicular involvement Absent Present
WBC count <50,000/mm3 >50,000/mm3
FAB Type L1 L2,L3
Cytogenetics Hyperdiploidy Hypodiploidy
Immunophenotype B-cell, early pre-B T cell
Translocation T(12,21),Notch 1,HOX 11 t(9,22),t(4,11)

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient came to the OPD with complaints of swelling over the cervical region. On examination, it is found to be painless lymphadenopathy along with the presence of splenomegaly. On HPE examination, the following picture given in the image is seen with the absence of centroblasts. Immunophenotyping shows CD23 negative, CD 19 and CD 20 positive.
Which of the following is false regarding the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical and biopsy picture points to Mantle cell lymphoma, which has its origin from naïve B cells, which are characterised by a lack of somatic hypermutation of the IgH gene (Due to the tumour arising from Naive B Cells).

Mantle cell lymphoma :

  • Tumor cells resemble the normal mantle zone B- cells which surround the germinal centre
  • Seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life
  • Has male predominance
  • Has (11;14) translocation (Option A)
  • IgH locus on – chromosome 14
  • Cyclin D1 locus on – chromosome 11
  • Overexpression of Cyclin D1 is seen (Option B)

Features:

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon – lymphomatoid polyposis (Option D)

Histology :

  • Nodal tumor cells may surround reactive germinal centres to produce a nodular appearance at low power or diffusely efface the node.
  • Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours
  • Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centres are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively

Immunophenotyping :

  • CD 5+
  • CD 23 negative
  • CD19 and  CD20 positive
  • Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or λ light chain)
  • The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with a history of swelling over the anterior part of the neck, fatigue, and weight loss for two months. On examination, the mass moves with deglutition. A biopsy from the patient's thyroid gland is shown below. Investigations reveal elevated plasma metanephrines, serum calcium, PTH, and calcitonin. She also gives a history of her mother undergoing surgery for a lump in the neck many years before. Which of the following is likely to result in the above condition?

choices.text: Gain of function mutation in RET
Loss of function mutation in RET
Gain of function mutation in K-RAS
Loss of function mutation in K-RAS

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes the features of MEN 2A syndrome, which includes medullary thyroid carcinoma (The given histopathology picture shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma and family history of thyroid surgery), parathyroid adenoma (elevated serum calcium, PTH, and calcitonin) and pheochromocytoma (elevated plasma metanephrines). The gain of function mutations in RET proto-oncogene occurs in MEN 2A syndrome.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia is characterised by the presence of tumors in two or more endocrine glands. It can be MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), or MEN 4.

MEN 1 is associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN type 2 comprises groups of disorders caused by gain-of-function mutations of the RET proto-oncogene at chromosomal locus 10q11.2. There are three variants:

  • MEN 2A, also known as MEN 2 (most common type)
  • MEN 2B, also known as MEN 3
  • MTC only

MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors.

MEN 2B is characterised by MTC, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

Other options

Option B: Loss of function mutation of RET gene leads to Hirschprung disease.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: Cancers associated with important oncogenes

Oncogenes

 Associated cancers

c-MYC

Burkitt’s lymphoma

Adenocarcinomas of the breast, lung, and colon

N-MYC

Neuroblastoma

L-MYC

Small-cell carcinoma of the lung
K-RAS Colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors
N-RAS

Melanoma

AML
H-RAS Bladder and kidney tumors

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding tumour markers is false?

choices.text: Biological and analytical variability are some of the commonly encountered disadvantages of tumour markers
No existing tumor biomarker possesses high accuracy for prognostic indication
Tumor markers have the sensitivity but not the specificity to diagnose cancers
Serum levels of AFP and CEA can be elevated in a variety of non-neoplastic conditions, limiting their value as screening tests

questions.solution:
Statement 3 is a false statement regarding tumour markers.

Biochemical assays for tumour-associated enzymes, hormones, and other tumour markers may aid in cancer diagnosis. They are also frequently helpful in tracking a tumour's response to treatment and identifying tumour recurrence. Nevertheless, they do not have both the sensitivity and specificity required to diagnose cancer.

Tumour biomarkers are substances synthesised by cancer cells or other body cells in response to cancer and released into circulation. 

The structural makeup of tumour biomarkers varies greatly. They can be simple molecules like catecholamines or well-characterized proteins like hormones, enzymes, or more diverse glycoproteins or mucins like carbohydrate antigen 125 (CA-125), which can be measured by antibodies. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) are examples of significant tumour biomarkers that are oncofetal antigens that are present in a normal foetus and are expressed at low levels by healthy tissues but at high concentrations by certain malignancies.

Disadvantages of tumour markers are:

  • No existing tumour biomarker possesses high specificity, sensitivity, accuracy and reproducibility rates, offering cost-effective screening, diagnosis, and prognostic indication.
  • Tumor markers cannot be used as standalone diagnostic markers for malignancies. Biological and analytical variability limit their usage. For example, tumour markers such as AFP are found to be elevated in non-neoplastic conditions like liver diseases. Another example is CEA which is elevated in conditions like ulcerative colitis, pancreatitis, etc. Hence, relying entirely on tumour biomarker assays may lead to inaccurate or incomplete diagnostic conclusions.

Therefore, it is pivotal for us to make use of the tumour markers along with other diagnostic methods (imaging studies, biopsies, or clinical evaluations) to establish a comprehensive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman who presented with a 3-month history of a painless firm lump in her breast's upper outer quadrant underwent breast conservative surgery and is now awaiting instructions on follow-up. What is the recommended advice regarding the follow-up for this patient?

choices.text: Annual mammograms of the treated and contralateral breast
Annual mammograms of the contralateral breast only
Annual mammograms of the contralateral breast only and Serum tumor markers
Annual mammograms of the treated and contralateral breast and Serum tumor markers

questions.solution:
For a patient with the given clinical scenario after treatment of breast cancer, the recommended follow-up advice consists of a routine physical examination once in 3 months for the first two years and annual mammograms of the treated and contralateral breast.

Mammography is the only imaging modality necessary for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. There is currently no role for tumour markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scans in follow-up.

Women who have had a mastectomy, including simple mastectomy, modified radical mastectomy, and radical mastectomy would not need further routine screening mammograms on that side, but will still need to have a yearly mammogram on the remaining breast.

The guidelines for follow-up are as follows,

Physical examination:

  • For the first 2 years: once every 3 months
  • For 3-5 years: once every 6 months
  • After 5 years: Annually

Mammography: Annually

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

Related Pearl: Hormonal therapy in breast carcinoma given for ER/PR-positive cases

Role:

  • Reduce risk of recurrence
  • Reduce risk of contralateral breast cancer
  • Reduce risk of progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma
Selective estrogen- receptor modulator Aromatase inhibitors Ovarian suppression/ ablation
  • Tamoxifen
  • Raloxifen
  • Arzoxifen
  • Fenoxifen
  • Anastrazole
  • Letrozole
  • Exemestane
  • Oophorectomy
  • GnRH analogues

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with vague abdominal pain for the last six months, and a recent blood investigation revealed elevated levels of serum CEA and CA 19-9. He also noticed spontaneously appearing and disappearing tender nodules (clots) under the skin at different locations, as shown below. Which of the other following conditions is most likely associated with his skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Buerger's disease is the other condition among the given options that is associated with the given skin lesions.

This patient with vague abdominal pain, elevated serum markers of CA19-9 and CEA, and skin showing features of migratory thrombophlebitis are consistent with a diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. Patients with Buerger’s disease can also present with migratory thrombophlebitis.

Buerger’s disease is a progressive non-atherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the upper and lower extremities.

Clinical features:

  • Typically presents in young male smokers, with symptoms beginning before age 40.
  • Patients initially present with foot, leg, arm, or hand claudication, which may progress to rest pain to calf claudication and eventually ischemic rest pain and ulcerations on the toes, feet, fingers and even gangrene.
  • A complete history should exclude diabetes, hyperlipidemia, or autoimmune disease as possible etiologies for the occlusive lesions.

Pathogenesis:

Smoking increases the level of carboxyhemoglobin, which causes vasospasm and hyperplasia of the intima of small and medium-sized vessels. This eventually results in thrombosis and obliteration of vessels, followed by segmental pan arteritis. Eventually, the artery, vein, and nerve are together involved, which causes rest pain (nerve involvement) and ischemia in the limb (arterial involvement).

Once blockage occurs, plenty of collaterals open up depending on the site of blockage to maintain blood supply to the ischaemic area, resulting in a compensatory peripheral vascular disease. If the patient continues to smoke, the disease progresses into the collaterals, blocking them eventually, leading to severe ischemia, which is called decompensatory peripheral vascular disease.

It is presently called critical limb ischemia. It causes rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene.

Investigations:

  • Arterial doppler and duplex scan (Doppler + B mode U/S)
  • Transfemoral retrograde angiogram through Seldinger technique
  • Characteristic angiographic findings show disease confinement to the distal circulation, usually infra popliteal and distal to the brachial artery. The occlusions are segmental and show “skip” lesions with extensive collateralisation, the so-called corkscrew collaterals.

Treatment:

  • Cessation of smoking is the definitive management. 
  • Drugs to improve circulation include
    • Pentoxifylline
    • Aspirin
    • Clopidogrel
    • Statins 
    • Cilostazol- Phosphodiesterase inhibitor is ideally used to improve circulation in the collaterals formed.
    • Vasodilators and anticoagulants have no role in the treatment.
  • Care of limb with Buerger’s exercise and positioning 
  • Surgical management may include lumbar sympathectomy and amputation according to the presenting features. 

Other options

Option A: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a pathological condition characterised by the obstruction of blood flow in the deep veins, resulting from impaired venous reflux mechanism. DVT is not associated with migratory thrombophlebitis.

Option C: Raynaud phenomenon is manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, causing pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis. It is seen in virtually all patients with systemic sclerosis or scleroderma and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases. Raynaud phenomenon is not associated with migratory thrombophlebitis.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis is the inflammation of the medium to large-sized arteries. It mainly affects the aortic arch and its branches. The most commonly affected artery is the subclavian artery. Patients will present with features of arm claudication, Raynaud's phenomenon, etc. They can also present with syncope, transient ischemic attack, abdominal pain, or chest pain, depending on the arteries involved. A biopsy of the affected artery will show pan arteritis with mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasionally giant cells. Takayasu arteritis is not associated with migratory thrombophlebitis.

questions.text: TP53 mutants can be discovered in the serum in all the following cancers except?
questions.solution:
In Bladder Cancer, TP53 mutants are found in Urine, and not in serum.

Meanwhile, Cell-Free DNA markers such as TP53 mutants are found in the serum in Colon, Lung and Pancreatic cancers.

questions.text:

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with pain in the right leg accompanied by symptoms of fever and fatigue. His X-ray shows onion peel appearance with extension into the bone marrow. Which of the following is associated with this condition?

choices.text: There is poor response to radio therapy

questions.solution:
This patient has pain in the limb with fever and fatigue with onion peel appearance on X-Ray with extension into the bone marrow. This is most likely Ewing's sarcoma. It is associated with an elevated serum LDH.

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have a balanced translocation between the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, and flat bones of the pelvis. Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm.

Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count, LDH levels (lactate dehydrogenase) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The common diagnostic test used for Ewing’s sarcoma is the detection of translocation t(11;22) (q24;q12). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round blue cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2. The tumor cells contain glycogen and are hence PAS positive and they are reticulin negative.

Preoperative chemotherapy with vincristine, ifosfamide, doxorubicin and etoposide results in extensive tumor necrosis and shrinkage. Wide excision may be combined with adjuvant radiotherapy if surgical margins are poor. Definitive radiotherapy rather than surgical excision may be advocated if it is non-resectable or metastasis has occurred. It is a radio-sensitive tumor.

Indicators of poor prognosis in patients with Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Presence of distant metastasis - worst prognostic factor
  • Size and location of the primary lesion
  • Presence of fever, anemia
  • Leukocytosis, raised ESR. 

Other Options:

Ewing's sarcoma is radio sensitive(Option A), reticulin negative(Option B) and associated with a t(11:22) (Option D) translocation.

Related Pearl: Important radiosenstive and radioresistant bone tumours

Radiosensitive tumors:

  1. Metastasis (except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which is radioresistant)
  2. Ewing's sarcoma
  3. Multiple myeloma
  4. Lymphoma

Radioresistant tumors:

  1. Osteosarcoma
  2. Chondrosarcoma
  3. Fibrosarcoma
  4. Malignant fibrous histiocytoma

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

decade

decade

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with complaints of discoloration on her face. An excisional biopsy was done, and histopathology findings are shown below. They stain positive for HMB - 45. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: Superficial spreading type is the most common variant
Mutation in the hedgehog signalling pathway
Mutation in receptor tyrosine kinase signalling pathway
Shows positive immunohistochemistry staining for S-100

questions.solution:
The given history and histopathology showing dense intracytoplasmic brownish-black melanin pigment are suggestive of malignant melanoma. Mutations in the hedgehog signaling pathway are associated with basal cell carcinoma and not malignant melanoma. 

Malignant melanoma primarily arises from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction but may also originate from mucosal surfaces of the oropharynx, nasopharynx, eyes, proximal esophagus, anorectal, and female genitalia. It includes a pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled. Amelanotic lesions appear as raised pink, purple, or flesh-colored skin papules. The diagnostic clue for melanoma is the ABCDE criteria.

It consists of

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variegation
  • Diameter of more than 6 mm 
  • Evolution or change

The image below shows a case of malignant melanoma.

Lentigo maligna, superficial spreading, acral lentiginous, and nodular are the variants of malignant melanoma. Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common variant (Option A) of malignant melanoma. It is more commonly seen on the trunk and proximal extremities. It usually arises from a pre-existing nevus after a chronic period of change in color and border. Mutations in cell cycle regulators, receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (Option C), and those that activate telomerase are associated with melanomas.

Markers for melanoma include:

  • S100 (Option D)
  • MELAN-A
  • HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

Related Pearl: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

  • Thickness (Breslow index)***
  • Sentinel node status***
  • Ulceration**
  • Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)
  • Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)
  • Age* (negative for older age)
  • Sex* (negative for males)
  • Location* (negative for head and neck)

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with unilateral proptosis. CT scan of the orbit shows poorly defined mass with homogenous density with adjacent bony destruction. Histopathology is shown below. The immunohistochemistry of the cells was Desmin positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and histopathology are suggestive of Rhabdomyosarcoma.

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the common soft tissue sarcomas of childhood and adolescence that may occur at virtually any anatomic site but are usually found in the head and neck (25%), genitourinary tract (24%), extremities (19%), and orbit (9%). Retroperitoneum and other sites account for the remainder of primary sites.

It is classified into three subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, and pleomorphic.

Type Histopathology
Embryonal 

Tumour consists of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma.

 Sarcoma botryoid is a variant that occurs in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile, bladder, and vagina.
Alveolar  Tumour consists of a network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli. 
Pleomorphic Tumour consists of large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumour cells.


Clinically, the tumour is usually aggressive, with unilateral proptosis when the orbit is involved. Swelling and redness of the overlying skin, diplopia may be present.


In immunohistochemistry, they are positive for 

  • Desmin 
  • Myoglobin
  • Myogenin
  • MyoD1
  • Vimentin.

Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.

Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastases.

Decision-making for management is based on histopathologic confirmation as well as the staging of orbital RMS, which includes imaging (MRI of primary tumour, chest-CT, Tc bone scan), pathology, and work-up for metastases(bone marrow biopsy)

  • Group I: Localized disease, completely resected (excisional biopsy).
  • Group II: Microscopic disease remaining after biopsy.
  • Group III: Gross residual disease remaining after biopsy.
  • Group IV: Distant metastasis present at onset.

The below image shows the histopathology of Orbital Rhabdomyosarcoma.
